mainPage.title: Nuxt 3 Interview Questions
mainPage.content:
Prepare for Your Nuxt 3 Interview

This comprehensive guide covers the most commonly asked Nuxt 3 interview questions, from fundamentals to advanced topics.

Topics Covered

  • Core Concepts: Rendering modes, file-based routing, auto-imports
  • Server-Side Rendering: Hydration, universal rendering, SSR pitfalls
  • Composables & Reactivity: Custom composables, Vue 3 reactivity
  • Performance: Optimization techniques, caching strategies

Interview Tips

Be prepared to explain concepts with practical examples and discuss trade-offs between different approaches. Hands-on experience with Nuxt 3 projects will give you confidence in answering scenario-based questions.

subpages.title: Core Concepts Questions
subpages.content:
Q: What are the different rendering modes in Nuxt 3?

Answer: Nuxt 3 supports multiple rendering modes:

  • Universal (SSR): Server-side rendering with client-side hydration
  • SPA: Single Page Application, client-only rendering
  • Static (SSG): Pre-rendered at build time
  • Hybrid: Different modes per route using routeRules

Q: How does file-based routing work in Nuxt 3?

Answer: Nuxt 3 automatically generates routes based on the file structure in the pages/ directory. Dynamic routes use square brackets: [id].vue, and nested routes mirror the folder structure.

Q: What is the difference between useFetch and useAsyncData?

Answer: useFetch is a wrapper around useAsyncData specifically for HTTP requests using $fetch. useAsyncData is more generic and can be used for any async operation.

subpages.title: SSR and Hydration Questions
subpages.content:
Q: What is hydration in the context of Nuxt 3?

Answer: Hydration is the process where the client-side Vue application takes over the server-rendered HTML. Vue attaches event listeners and makes the page interactive without re-rendering the entire DOM.

Q: What causes hydration mismatches and how do you fix them?

Answer: Hydration mismatches occur when server and client render different content. Common causes include:

  • Using browser-only APIs on the server (window, document)
  • Time-based values that differ between server and client
  • Random values without consistent seeding

Solutions: Use <ClientOnly> component, check import.meta.client, or use useState for shared state.

Q: When would you use the ClientOnly component?

Answer: Use <ClientOnly> for components that rely on browser APIs, third-party libraries without SSR support, or content that should only render client-side to avoid hydration issues.

subpages.title: Composables and State Questions
subpages.content:
Q: How do you create a custom composable in Nuxt 3?

Answer: Create a file in the composables/ directory with a function that starts with use:

// composables/useCounter.ts
export const useCounter = () => {
  const count = ref(0)
  const increment = () => count.value++
  return { count, increment }
}

It will be auto-imported throughout your application.

Q: What is the difference between ref and reactive?

Answer: ref wraps a single value and requires .value to access it. reactive creates a reactive proxy of an object but cannot be reassigned. ref is preferred for primitives and when reassignment is needed.

Q: How do you share state between components in Nuxt 3?

Answer: Use useState for simple shared state, Pinia stores for complex state management, or provide/inject for component tree scoping. useState is SSR-friendly and auto-imported.

subpages.title: Advanced Questions
subpages.content:
Q: How do you implement middleware in Nuxt 3?

Answer: Nuxt 3 supports three types of middleware:

  • Anonymous: Defined inline with definePageMeta
  • Named: Files in middleware/ directory
  • Global: Files with .global.ts suffix
// middleware/auth.ts
export default defineNuxtRouteMiddleware((to, from) => {
  if (!isAuthenticated()) {
    return navigateTo('/login')
  }
})

Q: How do you configure environment variables in Nuxt 3?

Answer: Use runtimeConfig in nuxt.config.ts. Public variables go under public key and are available client-side. Private variables stay on the server only.

Q: Explain the Nuxt 3 module system

Answer: Modules extend Nuxt functionality through hooks and the module API. They can add components, plugins, composables, and modify the build process. Use defineNuxtModule to create custom modules.
